elements.content: Bis(phenylthio)methane (L1) reacts with CuI to yield the 1D-coordination polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n (1) bearing cubane Cu4I4 clusters as connecting nodes. The crystal structures at 115, 155, 195, and 235 K provided evidence for a phase transition changing from the monoclinic space group C2/c to P21/c. The self-assembly process of CuI with bis(p-tolylthio)methane (L2), bis(4-methoxyphenylthio)methane (L3), and bis(4-bromo-phenylthio)methane (L4) affords the 1D-coordination polymers [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-Lx )2] n (x = 2, 3, or 4). Compounds 2 and 4 are isostructural with C2/c low temperature polymorph of 1, whereas the inversion centers and 2-fold axes are lost in 3 (space group Cc). The use of bis(m-tolylthio)methane (L5) has no impact on the composition and overall topology of the resulting 1D ribbon of [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L5)2] n (5). Even the coordination of the sterically crowded dithioether bis(5-tert-butyl-2-methylphenylthio)methane (L8) does not alter the network topology generating the 1D polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L8)2] n (8). The 1D polymer [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L1)2] (9) results from the coordination of L1 with CuBr in a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio. In contrast to the mean Cu···Cu distances, which are <2.8 Å noted for the Cu4(μ3-I)4 clusters in the 1D polymers 1–8, the Cu···Cu contact within the Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboids of 9 [2.9194(8) Å] is above the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu atoms. The structural arrangement of 1D polymer [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L3)2] n (11) is quite similar to that of 9. While the reaction of CuBr with L5 results in a similar 1D polymer [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L5)2] n (12), the reaction of CuBr with L2 leads to the dinuclear complex [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(η1-L2)4] (10) ligated by four pendent bis(p-tolylthio)methane ligands. The ligation of bis(o-tolylthio)methane, L6, on CuBr also yields a discrete complex [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(MeCN)2(η1-L6)2] (13) bearing MeCN and dangling dithioether ligands. A strong luminescence is detected for all CuI polymers, all exhibiting emission lifetimes in the microsecond time scale (i.e., phosphorescence). The polymers containing the Cu4I4 core (1–8) exhibit the typically observed low-energy band and sometimes a weaker high-energy band. The nature of the low-energy band was proposed based on literature DFT and TDDFT computations and is predicted to be a mixture of cluster-centered (CC*) and metal/halide-to-ligand charger transfer (M/XLCT). An approximate relationship between the Cu···Cu distance and the emission maxima corroborates the CC* contribution to the nature of the excited states. The emission of the rhomboid-containing materials is assigned to M/XLCT based on literature works on similar motifs.

elements.content: Methylene-bridged ArSCH2SAr ligands react with CuBr and CuI to form almost invariably 1D coordination polymers of general formula [Cu2Br2(ArSCH2SAr)2] n and [Cu4I4(ArSCH2SAr)2] n , where the clusters exhibit the typical rhomboid and closed cubane geometry, respectively, with temperature-dependent Cu···Cu distances. All these solids exhibit a weak microsecond-lived luminescence at 298 and 77 K arising from triplet metal/halide-to-ligand charge transfer (M/XLCT) excited states, but the Cu4I4 species also show the usual intense lower energy cluster-centered triplet emission (CC*).
elements.clean_text: Methylene-bridged ArSCH2SAr ligands react with CuBr and CuI to form almost invariably 1D coordination polymers of general formula [Cu2Br2(ArSCH2SAr)2] n  and [Cu4I4(ArSCH2SAr)2] n , where the clusters exhibit the typical rhomboid and closed cubane geometry, respectively, with temperature-dependent Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances. All these solids exhibit a weak microsecond-lived luminescence at 298 and 77 K arising from triplet metal/halide-to-ligand charge transfer (M/XLCT) excited states, but the Cu4I4 species also show the usual intense lower energy cluster-centered triplet emission (CC*).

elements.content: Bis(diphenylphosphino)methane exhibits a widespread use in coordination chemistry. A plethora of articles showed that this diphosphane Ph2PCH2PPh2 ligand may be coordinated in an η1-bonding, chelating, or bridging mode to form mono- and dinuclear complexes as well as polymetallic clusters. There are also some reports on structural aspects and luminescence properties of dppm-bridged di- and polynuclear Cu(I) compounds. Concurrently, its sulfur analogue, PhSCH2SPh, L1, attracted much less attention, although bis(phenylthio)methane also displays promising versatility in its coordination modes. Indeed, an η1-bonding mode has been reported for [(η5-C5Me5)IrCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)], [(η5-C5Me5)Fe(CO)2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)]][BF4], cis-[PtCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2], and trans-[PdCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2]. Other L1-containing complexes include [Rh(η1-PhSCH2SPh)3Cl3], [Ir(η1-PhSCH2SPh)3Cl3], and [Ru(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2Cl3·EtOH]. Upon treatment of L1 with [M(MeCN)4][ClO4]2, the chelate complexes [M(PhSCH2SPh)4](ClO4)2 (M = Pd, Pt) are formed. Other examples of chelate complexes include the salts [(OC)4Re(PhSCH2SPh)][BF4] and [(η5-C5H5)Fe(CO)(PhSCH2SPh)][BF4]. In addition, L1 is also known to act as bridging ligand, thus assembling A-frame complexes such as [Rh2Cl4(μ-CO)(μ2-PhSCH2SPh)2], polynuclear compounds, and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). For example, a chiral non-interpenetrated (10,3)-a net has been obtained by reaction of AgClO4 with L1. Reaction of L1 with HAuCl4 has been reported to yield a 1D supramolecular polymer formed through Au–Au interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Bis(diphenylphosphino)methane exhibits a widespread use in coordination chemistry. A plethora of articles showed that this diphosphane Ph2PCH2PPh2 ligand may be coordinated in an η1-bonding, chelating, or bridging mode to form mono- and dinuclear complexes as well as polymetallic clusters. There are also some reports on structural aspects and luminescence properties of dppm-bridged di- and polynuclear Cu(I) compounds. Concurrently, its sulfur analogue, PhSCH2SPh, L1, attracted much less attention, although bis(phenylthio)methane also displays promising versatility in its coordination modes. Indeed, an η1-bonding mode has been reported for [(η5-C5Me5)IrCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)], [(η5-C5Me5)Fe(CO)2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)]][BF4], cis-[PtCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2], and trans-[PdCl2(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2]. Other L1-containing complexes include [Rh(η1-PhSCH2SPh)3Cl3], [Ir(η1-PhSCH2SPh)3Cl3], and [Ru(η1-PhSCH2SPh)2Cl3⋅EtOH]. Upon treatment of L1 with [M(MeCN)4][ClO4]2, the chelate complexes [M(PhSCH2SPh)4](ClO4)2 (M = Pd, Pt) are formed. Other examples of chelate complexes include the salts [(OC)4Re(PhSCH2SPh)][BF4] and [(η5-C5H5)Fe(CO)(PhSCH2SPh)][BF4]. In addition, L1 is also known to act as bridging ligand, thus assembling A-frame complexes such as [Rh2Cl4(μ-CO)(μ2-PhSCH2SPh)2], polynuclear compounds, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). For example, a chiral non-interpenetrated (10,3)-a net has been obtained by reaction of AgClO4 with L1. Reaction of L1 with HAuCl4 has been reported to yield a 1D supramolecular polymer formed through Au-Au interactions.

elements.content: Because the interactions of nucleophiles (L) such as dialkylsulfides (RSR), phosphanes, amines, and pyridyl type ligands with copper(I) halides may lead to tetranuclear cubane-shaped Cu4X4L4 clusters exhibiting remarkable photophysical properties such as intense luminescence, long excited state lifetimes, and thermo- and solvochromism, some years ago we reported the coordination chemistry of L1 and PhSCH2CH2SPh to CuI in order to evaluate the influence of the spacer length on the resulting framework. With L1, the strongly luminescent coordination polymer [Cu4I4{μ-PhS2CH2SPh}2] n (1) was isolated and structurally characterized, in which the Cu4(μ3-I)4 cluster units are linked by two dithioether ligands giving rise to a 1D necklace structure.
elements.clean_text: Because the interactions of nucleophiles (L) such as dialkylsulfides (RSR), phosphanes, amines, and pyridyl type ligands with copper(I) halides may lead to tetranuclear cubane-shaped Cu4X4L4 clusters exhibiting remarkable photophysical properties such as intense luminescence, long excited state lifetimes, and thermo- and solvochromism, some years ago we reported the coordination chemistry of L1 and PhSCH2CH2SPh to CuI in order to evaluate the influence of the spacer length on the resulting framework. With L1, the strongly luminescent coordination polymer [Cu4I4{μ-PhS2CH2SPh}2] n  (1) was isolated and structurally characterized, in which the Cu4(μ3-I)4 cluster units are linked by two dithioether ligands giving rise to a 1D necklace structure.

elements.content: That the substitution pattern of an aryl group of an assembling ligand may exert an important effect on the structural features of CuX complexes is well documented. In order to illustrate the effect of a methyl group substitution adjacent to a pyridyl N-donor, Spicer et al. prepared three bis(pyridylmethyl)sulfide ligands and reacted them with CuI in a 1:2 ratio. The dimethylated ligand bis(6-methyl-2-pyridylmethyl)sulfide gives rise to a tetranuclear complex with two Cu2I2 bridges in which the Cu centers are four-coordinate. The ligand 2-(6-methylpyridyl)methyl(2-pyridyl)methylsulfide gives a tetranuclear complex, which contains two parallel Cu2I2 bridges. In each Cu2I2 bridge, one Cu center is three-coordinate, and the other is four-coordinate. Conversely, the ligand bis(2-pyridylmethyl)sulfide gives rise to a 1D coordination polymer with CuI chains. In all three cases, the coordination of the ligands occurs both by the sulfide function and by the pyridyl nitrogens. It was concluded that the structural differences were a result of both the electronic and steric effects arising from the methyl substitution of the pyridine donors and that none of the effects completely dominate.

The ligand 2-(6-methylpyridyl)methyl(2-pyridyl)methylsulfide gives a tetranuclear complex, which contains two parallel Cu2I2 bridges. In each Cu2I2 bridge, one Cu center is three-coordinate, and the other is four-coordinate. Conversely, the ligand bis(2-pyridylmethyl)sulfide gives rise to a 1D coordination polymer with CuI chains. It was concluded that the structural differences were a result of both the electronic and steric effects arising from the methyl substitution of the pyridine donors and that none of the effects completely dominate.

elements.content: Our groups also observed an important impact of the substitution pattern of the aryl group (aryl = p-Tol vs Ph) on the resulting polymer structure upon reaction of CuI with 1,4-bis(aryl)butane. In the former case, an interpenetrated 2D [Cu4I4{μ-PhS(CH2)4SPh}2] n polymer was obtained whose network is built upon Cu4(μ3-I)4 cubane-like clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) interconnected by bridging bis(phenylthio)butane ligands. Surprisingly, the a priori “innocent” replacement of S-Ph by S-p-Tol caused a dramatic effect on the polymer topology and nuclearity of the SBUs. Under identical reaction conditions, the 2D polymer [(Cu2I2){μ-p-TolS(CH2)4STol-p}2] n was formed, which consists of parallel-arranged infinite inorganic staircase ribbons that are interconnected by the dithioether ligands. These stepped ribbons are constructed by dinuclear Cu(μ2-I)2Cu units with a close Cu···Cu separation of 2.798(2) Å, which are in weak contact [3.577 Å] with the neighboring rhomboids through μ3-bridging iodo atoms. We also reported recently on the topological differences encountered upon reaction of CuI and CuBr with 1,5-bis(phenylthio)pentane and 1,5-bis(p-tolylthio)pentane, respectively. A dramatic impact on the dimensionality of the MOF (3D vs 2D) and nuclearity of the SBU (Cu6I6 vs Cu4I4) was also encountered when CuI was reacted with the alkyne-dithioethers PhSCH2CCCH2SPh and p-TolSCH2CCCH2STol-p, respectively.

elements.content: In an attempt to establish a relationship between the structure of the bridging ligand and the halide on the resulting copper(I)-containing materials, we were therefore intrigued whether similar structural variations may be induced by a systematic variation of the aryl group in bis(arylthio)methane ligands ArSCH2SAr and their complexation with CuX (X = Br, I). We now report the structural features and photophysical properties of the resulting luminescent coordination polymers. Moreover, some relationships between the metric parameters of Cu4(μ3-I)4 clusters and temperature have been evaluated by X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: We previously reported the reaction of CuI with L1 in acetonitrile in a 2:1 molar ratio giving the luminescent 1D coordination polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n (1) (Scheme ). The X-ray powder diffraction patterns indicated that the modification of the reaction stoichiometry, for example, 1:1 vs 1:2, had no influence on the composition of the resulting material and only the polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n was formed. The crystal structure of [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n at 173 K has been already published, and it consists of cubane-like Cu4I4 clusters linked by bridging dithioether ligands to form an infinite necklace chain. Bearing in mind the wish to establish correlations between the dimensions of the SBU cubanes Cu4I4, their volumes V(Cu4) and V(I4), the mean Cu···Cu distances, and the photophysical properties as a function of temperature, we have reexamined the structure of 1 at four different temperatures (Table S1, ). Similarly to the previous 173 K data, the low temperature measurements (115, 155, and 195 K, 1A) reveal the same monoclinic C2/c space group with four cubane-like Cu4I4 SBUs in the unit cell placed over the 2-fold axes located at 0, y, 1/4; 0, y, 3/4; 1/2, y, 1/4, and 1/2, y, 1/4. There are two chains crossing the conventional unit cell, zigzagging over the c glide planes and running parallel to the crystal Z direction at 0, 0, z and 1/2, 1/2, z (Figure S1 in the ). Each chain contributes two SBUs for the conventional unit cell contents. Noteworthy, the centroids of Cu4I4 cubanes are very close to the c glide planes of C2/c (deviation of 0.07 Å) giving rise to the essentially linear (Cu4I4) n chains.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Reactions of CuI with ArSCH2SAr

We previously reported the reaction of CuI with L1 in acetonitrile in a 2:1 molar ratio giving the luminescent 1D coordination polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n  (1) (Scheme ). The X-ray powder diffraction patterns indicated that the modification of the reaction stoichiometry, for example, 1:1 vs 1:2, had no influence on the composition of the resulting material and only the polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n  was formed. The crystal structure of [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n  at 173 K has been already published, and it consists of cubane-like Cu4I4 clusters linked by bridging dithioether ligands to form an infinite necklace chain. Bearing in mind the wish to establish correlations between the dimensions of the SBU cubanes Cu4I4, their volumes V(Cu4) and V(I4), the mean Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances, and the photophysical properties as a function of temperature, we have reexamined the structure of 1 at four different temperatures (Table S1, ). Similarly to the previous 173 K data, the low temperature measurements (115, 155, and 195 K, 1A) reveal the same monoclinic C2/c space group with four cubane-like Cu4I4 SBUs in the unit cell placed over the 2-fold axes located at 0, y, 1/4; 0, y, 3/4; 1/2, y, 1/4, and 1/2, y, 1/4. There are two chains crossing the conventional unit cell, zigzagging over the c glide planes and running parallel to the crystal Z direction at 0, 0, z and 1/2, 1/2, z (Figure S1 in the ). Each chain contributes two SBUs for the conventional unit cell contents. Noteworthy, the centroids of Cu4I4 cubanes are very close to the c glide planes of C2/c (deviation of 0.07 Å) giving rise to the essentially linear (Cu4I4) n  chains.

Unexpectedly, the 235 K X-ray data indicate a change in space group from C2/c to P21/c. The topology of the chain structure remains similar to that found in the low temperature phase (Figure ), but the Cu4I4 SBUs lost their 2-fold symmetry. Similarly to the low temperature phase, the chain runs over the c glide plane (x, 0.25, z; Figure S2 in the ) now in the P21/c space group, but the centroid of the Cu4I4 cubane lies 0.415 Å away from this plane (Table ) rendering the chain much more zigzagging than in the low temperature phase (C2/c group).

The mean Cu–Cu distance (2.724 Å at 235 K) and the volume of the Cu4 tetrahedron (2.370 Å3 at 235 K) increase more rapidly than expected from linear correlations valid for 115 to 195 K structures (Figure ; the extrapolated values are, respectively, 2.714 and 2.338 Å3 at 235 K). Noteworthy, the Cu–Cu distances and Cu4 tetrahedron volumes increase monotonically upon warming from 115 to 195 K as usually observed. The previously reported mean Cu–Cu distances (d Cu...Cu) and the Cu4 tetrahedron volumes increase by 1.4% (2.7562 to 2.7944 Å) and 4.4% (2.460 to 2.569 Å3), respectively, in the 1D [(Et2S)3{Cu4(μ3-I)4}] n structure and by 1.8% (2.7265 to 2.7750 Å) and 5.4% (2.387 to 2.516 Å3) in [Cu4I4{μ-nBuS(CH2)4SnBu}2] n from 115 to 275 K. An increase of 1.25% (d Cu...Cu) and of 3.95% (V(Cu4)) is observed in 1 in the 120 K range (115 to 235 K) and should reach at least 1.9% (d Cu...Cu, 2.741 Å) and 6.1% (V(Cu4), 2.420 Å3) at 275 K by linear extrapolation of the segments (formed by 195 and 235 K data) of the graph presented in Figure . These last values are given on the assumption that the phase transition C2/c to P21/c occurs just over 195 K, but in fact we only know that this transition takes place between 195 and 235 K. For any intermediate temperature, the slopes corresponding to the P21/c space group will still be higher than those starting from 195 K. Consequently, the expansion of Cu4 tetrahedron will certainly be larger than 1.9% (d Cu...Cu) and 6.1% (V(Cu4)). Such an accelerated dilatation may be responsible of some degradation of the crystal upon warming as evidenced by the poor and untreatable quality of intensity measurements for 1B at 275 K. However, the unit cell volume increases only by 3.3 Å3 from 195 to 235 K (Table S1, ). The superposition of the structures at 115 and 195 K (Figure , left) and at 195 and 235 K (Figure , right) shows very little or no change in the low temperature C2/c phase, whereas an appreciable modification of phenyl ring conformations occurs upon the phase transition to P21/c (1A to 1B). Further changes of phenyl ring conformations at higher temperatures may lead to the destruction of crystal periodic structure at higher temperatures.

elements.content: In order to address the influence of substitution at the phenyl para-position, CuI was first reacted with bis(p-tolylthio)methane, L2, in a 2:1 CuI/ligand ratio under analogous conditions to its reaction with L1 (Scheme ). An X-ray diffraction study at 173 K (Table S2, ) revealed that the resulting colorless polymer has the general formula [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L2)2] n (2) and like the low-temperature form of [Cu4I4(μ-L1)2] n (1A), it crystallizes in C2/c space group. Changing the metal-to-ligand ratio to 1:1 does not influence the composition of the material.

elements.content: The tetranuclear Cu4(μ3-I)4 units in 2 are also doubly bridged by the dithioether ligands to form a 1D ribbon (Figure ). This tetranuclear Cu4 cluster exhibits a 2-fold crystallographic symmetry, and the Cu···Cu distances range between 2.652(3) and 2.829(2) Å. Their mean separation in [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L2)2] n (2) is somewhat larger than that found in [Cu4I4(μ-L1)2] n (1A) (2.738 vs 2.678 Å at 173 K) but still remains below to the sum of the van der Waals radii (2.8 Å) of two copper atoms. The average Cu–S bond length is also slightly longer (2.324(3) Å) than that observed for 1A (2.297(2) Å at 173 K). The Cu–I bond lengths fall in the usual range of 2.634(2)–2.756(2) Å (Table ). The 1D ribbons run over the c glide planes with deviation of the centroid of the Cu4I4 cubane from these planes reaching 0.139 Å (zigzagging ribbons, Figure S3, ).

elements.content: Pursuing the idea of CuI assemblies with para-substituted aryl dithioethers, the reaction of CuI with bis(4-methoxyphenylthio)methane, L3, in a 2:1 CuI-to-ligand ratio was conducted in MeCN and afforded a colorless polymeric material featuring a similar network topology as compounds 1A and 2 (Scheme ). An X-ray diffraction study (Figure ) performed at 173 K revealed that the resulting polymer [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L3)2] n (3) does not crystallize like 1A and 2 in the monoclinic space group C2/c, but in Cc; it exhibits a similar 1D polymer topology. In fact, the inversion centers and 2-fold axes are lost in 3 leading, like in 1A, 2, and 4, to a topology with 1D ribbons zigzagging over the c glide planes. The Cu···Cu distances of the Cu4(μ3-I)4 cores range from 2.641(1) to 2.824(1) Å and the mean M···M separation noted in [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L3)2] n (3) (2.736 Å) is quite close to that of 2 (Table ). The Cu4I4 cubane centroids deviate by 0.170 Å from the c glide planes (Table , Figure S4, ).

elements.content: The para-substituted di(bromophenylthio)methane ligand, L4, reacts with CuI to also form the same type of 1D coordination polymer, 4. Indeed, an X-ray analysis shows that 4 crystallizes once more in the C2/c space group and contains closed-cubane Cu4I4 SBUs placed over the 2-fold axes and is built of 1D chains running over the c glide planes (Figure and Figure S5, ) with a Cu4I4 centroid deviations of 0.160 Å (Table ). The 1D ribbon structure is therefore reminiscent of those in 1, 2, and 3. Similarly to polymer 1, X-ray data for 4 have been collected at five temperatures (between 115 and 275 K, Table S3, ). The mean Cu···Cu distances (Å) and the volumes of distorted Cu4 tetrahedrons (Å3) regularly increase from 2.728 to 2.762 (1.2%) and 2.374 to 2.462 (3.7%), respectively, in the 160 K range (Figure ). On the other hand, the volumes of the I4 tetrahedrons vary very little and irregularly from 10.384 (235 K) to 10.404 Å3 (195 K) in the 160 K range.

elements.content: Ortho- and meta-substituted aryl-containing ligands were also studied. The bis(m-tolylthio)methane ligand, L5, reacts with CuI in a 2:1 CuI/ligand ratio under the usual conditions (Scheme , MeCN as the solvent). Pale yellow crystals of composition [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L5)2] n (5) were isolated (73% yield) and subjected to an X-ray diffraction study. Unfortunately, twinned crystals were stubbornly obtained. Attempts to obtain suitable single crystals from EtCN also failed, once again leading to twinned crystals. Nevertheless, diffraction data have successfully been collected on two crystals issued from both MeCN and EtCN. Both crystal analyses indicate the presence of the non-centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pca21. A somewhat better data set and resolution of the structure was obtained on a crystal grown in acetonitrile (Table and Table S2, , and Figure ). The structure also exhibits 1D chains with Cu4I4 SBUs bridged by dithioethers like those of 1–4. However, due to twinning (Flack’s absolute structure parameter close to 0.5), there are two independent chains running now over a glide planes of the Pca21 space group (Figure S6, ). Moreover, because the 2-fold axes of the C2/c space group (compounds 1–4) are no longer present in the Pca21 structure, there is no local symmetry in both crystallographically independent Cu4I4 cubanes (5A built with Cu1 to Cu4 atoms and 5B built with Cu5 to Cu8 atoms, see also Figure ). Nevertheless, the metric parameters for 5 gathered in Table do not exhibit any particular anomaly among the Cu4I4 series except for the largest deviations of Cu4I4 centroids away from the glide planes (some 0.45 Å). Consequently, the ribbons in 5 exhibit the largest deviations from linearity within the family of all structures based on Cu4I4 cluster reported in this paper.

elements.content: CuI was also treated with bis(o-tolylthio)methane, L6, but unfortunately no crystal suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis was obtained for this resulting colorless product. However, the elemental analyses are consistent with a composition as [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}{μ-L6}2] n (6), but the dimensionality of 6 remains speculative. Recently, Castillo et al. reported the reaction of CuI with bis(2,4-dimethylphenylthio)methane (L7) with different stoichiometries. A solid of composition [{Cu4I4}(L7)2(MeCN)2] n was isolated when CuI-to-ligand molar ratios of 1:2 and 1:1 were used, and a polymeric structural motif similar to that of compounds 1–4 was tentatively proposed. Raising the metal-to-ligand ratio to 4:1 produced a crystallographically characterized 12-membered macrocycle (Scheme ), where two [Cu4(μ3-I)4] clusters (average Cu···Cu distance 2.690(1) Å) are ligated by two MeCN and two bridging dithioether ligands.

This research group also reported the reaction of the bis(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenylthio)methane ligand with CuI but failed to isolate any crystalline product, which was attributed to the high degree of steric hindrance exerted by the bulky tert-butyl group. Intrigued by this possible reason, the hitherto unknown isomeric ligand bis(5-tert-butyl-2-methylphenylthio)methane (L8) bearing a methyl group in ortho-position and the tert-butyl group in the meta-position of the aryl cycle was reacted with CuI. The synthesis of this sterically crowded ligand was achieved by reacting 2 equiv of 5-tert-butyl-2-methylbenzenethiolate with CH2Cl2 in ethanol as the reaction medium. Complexation of L8 with CuI in MeCN produced a yellowish solid of composition [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L8)2] n (8), crystallizing again in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Despite the ortho- (Me) and meta-substitutions (t-Bu) on the aryl groups of L8, a 1D coordination polymer has been generated via the self-assembly process once again, in which the [Cu4(μ3-I)4] SBUs are interconnected by two bridging dithioether ligands (Figure ). The resulting 1D polymer 8 is located over the c glide plane of the C2/c group similar to the structures for the para-substituted compounds 1, 2, and 4 (Figure S7, ).

elements.content: Each copper atom of the tetranuclear Cu4(μ3-I)4 core in 8 is ligated by one S–Ar group (Figure ), the mean Cu–S bond length of 2.3225 Å being almost identical to that of [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L2)2] n (2). Like in polymers 1, 2, and 4, two Cu atoms within the distorted tetrahedral Cu4 cluster are related by 2-fold axis symmetry. The individual Cu···Cu distances are quite different and range between 2.582(1) and 2.868(1) Å with a mean distance of 2.722 Å at 173 K (Table ). Despite the steric congestion caused by the aryl groups in L8, the Cu···Cu distances in 8 are surprisingly not elongated with respect to those determined for compounds 2–5. This observation contrasts with the coordination polymers [Cu4I4{μ-RS(CH2)4SR}2] n (R = n-Bu, R = t-Bu). In these 2D grid-shaped networks, the steric effect of t-BuS versus n-BuS was clearly evidenced. Despite the resemblance of the topologies of the networks, a striking difference concerning the mean Cu···Cu distances of 2.727(1) and 2.911(2) Å for [Cu4I4{μ-n-BuS(CH2)4SBu-n}2] n and [Cu4I4{μ-t-BuS(CH2)4SBu-t}2] n was noticed. Conclusively, this marked elongation of the intermetallic contacts in the Cu4I4 SBU of the latter material is most likely due to steric crowding exerted by the bulky -S-t-Bu groups. This latter 2D polymer exhibits the longest Cu···Cu distances so far known for compounds containing this Cu4I4S4 cluster.

elements.content: Table shows that the mean Cu···Cu distance in 8 falls in the range observed for 1–5. However, the range for the individual Cu···Cu distances in 8 is 0.29 Å, which is clearly larger than that observed for the other Cu4I4 SBUs (0.15–0.24 Å). Moreover, Figure reporting the volumes of Cu4 tetrahedrons as a function of the mean Cu···Cu distances shows that 8 deviates somewhat from the linear correlation. The regression coefficients, R 2, are 0.968 and 0.997 for the linear correlation with and without the data for 8, respectively. The position of 8 on the graph suggests that the Cu4 tetrahedron volume is smaller than expected for a mean Cu···Cu distance of 2.722 Å and must be due to a larger distortion of this tetrahedron.

elements.content: The data presented in Figure indicate that the geometrical parameters related to the copper clusters are the smallest for the nonsubstituted polymer 1A. Conversely, the largest parameters correspond to the para substitutions on aryl groups with methyl (polymer 2), methoxy (polymer 3), and bromide (polymer 4). Table provides some additional relevant information on the geometric parameters. First, generally the Cu–S distances are quite insensitive to the nature of the ligand with all individual distances in all compounds ranging only from 2.302(1) in 1A to 2.336(1) Å in 8 with the average values almost indistinguishable from this interval (2.303–2.324 Å). Consequently the Cu–S bond lengths (the most covalent bond in the Cu4I4S4 core) are not specific for a given structure. The variations of individual Cu–I bonds lengths are much larger as they range from 2.6162(7) Å in 5A to 2.7946(9) Å in 8 (range of 0.18 Å). However, a narrow range of mean values is noted (smallest 2.673 for 5A to largest 2.693 Å for 2). The most sensitive metric parameter is the Cu···Cu individual distance, which varies from 2.625(3) for 3 to 2.868(1) Å for 8 (i.e., range of 0.24 Å) with mean values from 2.698 (1A) to 2.738 Å (2). The individual Cu4 tetrahedron volumes vary from 2.299 (1A) to 2.404 Å3 (2), which corresponds to a 4.5% variation. The individual volumes of the I4 tetrahedrons vary from 10.568 (1A) to 9.986 Å3 (8). The value for 8 is certainly lower than expected because of the steric influence of the bulky disubstituted dithioether ligand present in 8. The variations of these volumes for all structures are 5.8%, but without that of 8, it decreases to 3.5%. Finally for all 1–8 structures, the 1D chains are placed over the glide planes. The most linear (i.e., smallest deviation of Cu4 centroid from this plane) is found in compound 1A bearing the nonsubstituted dithioether L1, whereas its higher temperature phase exhibits a highly zigzagging polymer structure. The deviation from linearity of the ribbon is still higher in 5 with meta-methyl substituted ligand L5.

elements.content: Despite the rapidly growing number of MOFs in which CuI-containing SBUs are connected through acyclic dithioethers RS∩SR reported in the literature, there are only few examples of related CuBr-containing compounds. Except for our recently reported 1D [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-PhS(CH2)3SPh}2] n and [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-ArS(CH2)5SAr}2] n polymers (Ar = Ph, p-Tol), the only other example of a CuBr coordination polymer assembled with acyclic dithioether is [Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu{μ-p-EtSCH2C6H4C6H4CH2SEt-p}2] n . Noteworthy, the seemingly “innocent” alteration of the aromatic cycle in [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-ArS(CH2)5SAr}2] n has a significant impact on the connectivity within the 1D ribbons (Scheme ). Furthermore, the Cu···Cu distance within the dinuclear SBUs increases from 2.919 Å in the case of [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-p-TolS(CH2)5STol-p}] to 3.034 Å in [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-p-TolS(CH2)5STol-p}] n .

Despite the rapidly growing number of MOFs in which CuI-containing SBUs are connected through acyclic dithioethers RS∩SR reported in the literature, there are only few examples of related CuBr-containing compounds. Except for our recently reported 1D [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-PhS(CH2)3SPh}2] n  and [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-ArS(CH2)5SAr}2] n  polymers (Ar = Ph, p-Tol), the only other example of a CuBr coordination polymer assembled with acyclic dithioether is [Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu{μ-p-EtSCH2C6H4C6H4CH2SEt-p}2] n . Noteworthy, the seemingly "innocent" alteration of the aromatic cycle in [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-ArS(CH2)5SAr}2] n  has a significant impact on the connectivity within the 1D ribbons (Scheme ). Furthermore, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance within the dinuclear SBUs increases from 2.919 Å in the case of [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-p-TolS(CH2)5STol-p}] to 3.034 Å in [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-p-TolS(CH2)5STol-p}] n .

With the aim to evaluate the influence of the halide ion on the self-assembly process with ArSCH2SAr, L1 was reacted with CuBr (Scheme ). Attempts to isolate a homogeneous product when CuBr was mixed with L1 in a 2:1 ratio in MeCN failed. However, when the two reagents were combined in a 1:1 molar ratio, crystals of a 1D coordination polymer of the type [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L1)2] (9) were obtained and were studied by X-ray diffraction analysis (Table S4, ). In this case, dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboids act as connection nodes linked by two μ2-PhSCH2SPh ligands hence generating a 1D ribbon (Figure ). This structural arrangement compares with the aforementioned polymer [Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu(μ-p-EtSCH2C6H4–C6H4CH2SEt-p}2] n , in which two 2,2′-bis(ethylthiomethyl)biphenyl ligands span dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu SBUs giving rise to an infinite 1D strand as encountered in 9. The mean Cu–Br bond length of the latter polymer is somewhat longer than that for 9 [2.518(1) vs 2.4611(8) Å]. The separations between the metal centers [2.918 vs 2.9191(8) Å] are the same. Moreover, the average Cu–S bond distances are slightly longer than that for [Cu4I4(μ-L1)2] n [2.324(3) vs 2.297(2) Å]. A comparison of the average Cu–S bond distances with those for [Cu4I4(μ-L1)2] n [2.309(1) vs 2.297(2) Å] reveals that the nature of the halide does not affect the length of this bond. Noteworthy, according to Murray et al. there is no reaction between L1 and CuBr2 in acetone or ethanol.

Attempting to prepare the hitherto unknown Cu4(μ3-Br)4S4 cluster unit, we reacted CuBr with L2 in a 2:1 ratio in MeCN solution. Unfortunately, the only crystalline product that could be isolated was the known 1D polymeric stair-type MeCN adduct [CuBr(MeCN)] n (orthorhombic, space group Pbnm). Large crystals were also grown from a MeCN/Et2O mixture at −25 °C when CuBr was mixed with L2 in a 1:1 ratio. Surprisingly, attempts to isolate a material with a composition similar to that of 9 failed.

elements.content: In contrast to compound 9, this mildly air-sensitive product, which was isolated in 35% yield, rapidly redissolves at room temperature. Indeed, the unusual discrete dinuclear complex [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(η1-L2)4] (10) was formed instead of the anticipated coordination polymer (Scheme ). The yield was improved to 54% when a 2:1 ligand-to-CuBr molar ratio was used. An X-ray diffraction study revealed that this centrosymmetric “0D” species is ligated by four pendent bis(p-tolylthio)methane ligands (Figure ). Within the dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboid core, the Cu···Cu contact of 2.807(1) Å is at the limit of the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu atoms. Longer Cu···Cu distances for the complexes [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(1-oxa-4,7-dithiacyclononane)2] (2.852(1) Å) and [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(7,8,16,17-tetrahydro-5H,10H-dibenz[1,4,8,11]dioxadithiacyclotetradecine-S,S′)2] (2.919(4) Å) ligated by a 14-membered dioxadithiamacrocycle were recently reported. The Cu–Br bond lengths in the centrosymmetric rhomboid differ by 0.08 Å (2.4418(3) and 2.5239(3) Å), an asymmetry often seen in Cu2Br2 cores. However, the rhomboids are essentially symmetric in 9 (Cu1–Br1 = 2.4749(8), 2.4827(8) Å; Cu2–Br2 = 2.4486(8), 2.4382(8) Å), where a difference of only ∼0.01 Å is noted. The Cu–Br–Cu angle of 10 is more acute than that of 9 [68.91(2)° vs 72.8(1)°] due to their different Cu···Cu separations [9, 2.9192(8) Å, and 10, 2.807(1) Å]. The self-assembly process of CuBr with L3 in a 1:1 ratio was also investigated, and large colorless crystals were obtained in 66% yield from a MeCN solution at 5 °C (Scheme ).

An X-ray diffraction study revealed that this centrosymmetric "0D" species is ligated by four pendent bis(p-tolylthio)methane ligands (Figure ). Within the dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboid core, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contact of 2.807(1) Å is at the limit of the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu atoms. Longer Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances for the complexes [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(1-oxa-4,7-dithiacyclononane)2] (2.852(1) Å) and [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(7,8,16,17-tetrahydro-5H,10H-dibenz[1,4,8,11]dioxadithiacyclotetradecine-S,S')2] (2.919(4) Å) ligated by a 14-membered dioxadithiamacrocycle were recently reported. The Cu-Br bond lengths in the centrosymmetric rhomboid differ by 0.08 Å (2.4418(3) and 2.5239(3) Å), an asymmetry often seen in Cu2Br2 cores. However, the rhomboids are essentially symmetric in 9 (Cu1-Br1 = 2.4749(8), 2.4827(8) Å; Cu2-Br2 = 2.4486(8), 2.4382(8) Å), where a difference of only ~0.01 Å is noted. The Cu-Br-Cu angle of 10 is more acute than that of 9 [68.91(2)° vs 72.8(1)°] due to their different Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations [9, 2.9192(8) Å, and 10, 2.807(1) Å]. The self-assembly process of CuBr with L3 in a 1:1 ratio was also investigated, and large colorless crystals were obtained in 66% yield from a MeCN solution at 5 °C (Scheme ).

elements.content: The structural arrangement of the resulting 1D [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L3)2] polymer (11) is quite similar to that of 9, despite different monoclinic space groups (Pn vs P21/c). Its ribbon nature (along the crystal X axis) is illustrated in Figure . Figure S8, , shows the roughly orthogonal disposition of the chains. The central rhomboid of the Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu SBU is essentially symmetric with Cu–Br distances of 2.463(1) and 2.457(1) Å. The Cu···Cu distance of 2.810(2) Å in 11 is clearly shorter than that found in the analogous nonsubstituted 1D polymer compound 9 (2.9192(8) Å), but it is the same as in the 0D molecular structure of 10 (2.8099(4) Å). Consequently, it seems that there is no clear tendency for the evolution of Cu···Cu distances in compounds within the CuBr series with different para-substitutions (H, Me, OMe) of the ArSCH2SAr dithioethers. The complexation of the meta-substituted ligand L5 with CuBr in a 1:1 molar ratio provided a colorless crystalline solid, which was crystallographically characterized to be a 1D polymer [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(L5)2] n (12).

elements.content: The ribbon of polymer 12 (Figure ) exhibits centrosymmetric Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboids interconnected through bridging ligands L5 like in polymer 11. The Cu···Cu separation of 2.8503(7) is also quite close that found in polymer 11. More interestingly, the ribbons in 12 run over the c glide planes of the C2/c space group (Figure S9, ). The same feature was also encountered in all CuI-containing polymers 1–8. Thus, the topology of the ribbons in 12 is the sole common property between the CuI and CuBr structural series, despite different SBUs (Cu4I4 vs Cu2Br2). Noteworthy, the C1 and C8 methyl carbon atoms of the ArSCH2SAr bridges in 12 lay on the 2-fold axes.

elements.content: A MeCN ligand and two bridging bromides complete the coordination sphere around the Cu atom. The Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboid core is more dissymmetric than that of 10 with Cu–Br bond lengths of 2.4436(2) and 2.6135(2) Å (difference of 0.17 Å, compared with 0.08 Å in 10). Another structural difference is the Cu···Cu separation, which is markedly more elongated compared with that of 10 [3.0667(4) vs 2.807(1) Å]. Consequently, the Cu–Br–Cu# angle of 74.572(7)° is the most widened one within the series 9–13. The Cu–N distance matches well that reported for [CuBr(MeCN)] n polymer [1.953(1) vs 1.957(1) Å]. On a theoretical stand point (extended Hückel computations), the nature of the Cu···Cu interactions in the rhomboid structures of the type L2Cu(μ-X)2CuL2 (X = halide; L = neutral ligand, notably phosphines) was addressed by Eisenstein and collaborators. The two main conclusions are that the potential well (in the graph d(Cu···Cu) vs energy) is very shallow and that the distance is very long (d(Cu···Cu) > 2.9 Å) with very weak interactions arising from s and p metal orbitals. The crystallographically evaluated Cu···Cu distances for the S2Cu(μ-Br)2CuS2 frames here are all long as well (d(Cu···Cu) > 2.8 Å). Consequently, the Cu···Cu interactions are considered to be weak as well.

The crystallographically evaluated Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances for the S2Cu(μ-Br)2CuS2 frames here are all long as well (d(Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) > 2.8 Å). elements.content: More recently, Pike and his collaborators investigated a series of materials built upon the L2Cu(μ-I)2CuL2 units (L = 2-pyridyl-functionalized piperazines). In these cases, the Cu···Cu separations were shorter (2.55 < d(Cu···Cu) < 2.65 Å), but no evidence for Cu···Cu interactions was provided for these tetracoordinated species. We previously noted an elongation of the metal–metal contacts for the 2D [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}{μ-PhS(CH2)3SPh}2] n and [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{{μ-PhS(CH2)2SPh}2] n polymers when passing from Br– to I– [2.785(1) vs 2.826(10) Å]. This trend was also observed for the isomorphous 1D polymers [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}2{μ-PhS(CH2)5SPh}2] n and [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-PhS(CH2)5SPh}2] n [2.9190(3) vs 3.009(1) Å]. However, almost identical Cu···Cu separations have been determined for the 1D polymers [{Cu(μ2-X)2Cu}2{μ-CyS(CH2)4SCy}2] n (X = I (3.241 Å), Br (3.215 Å)), demonstrating that with the 1,4-bis(cyclohexylthio)butane ligand the effect of the bridging halide is negligible. However, within the series of isomorphous binuclear complexes [LCu(μ2-X)2L] (L = (8-phenylthionaphth-1-yl)diphenylphosphine; X = I, Br, Cl), a shortening of the Cu···Cu separation has been noticed when the halide size increases.

elements.content: In this work, all mean Cu···Cu distances are shorter in the CuI compounds than in the CuBr compounds. But the different nuclearities (Cu2Br2 vs Cu4I4) do not allow a comparison and discussion on the halide influence (different atomic radii, Cu–X bond lengths, electronegativity, softness according Pearson’s HSAB concept, etc.) on the Cu···Cu distances. Therefore, a targeted synthesis of Cu4Br4S4 compounds of the closed-cubane type remains a challenge. Noteworthy, the Cu···Cu distances of the tetrahedron lengthen in the order I < Br < Cl within the series [Cu4(μ3-X)4(PR3)4] (X = Cl, Br, I; R = Et, Ph). No clear trend is yet observed for thioether-ligated Cu(I) compounds. More comparative data are necessary.

elements.content: The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 8 exhibit two plateaus (Figure S10, ). The first one spreads from room temperature to ∼200 °C for polymers 1, 2, 5 and 8 and from room temperature to about 225 °C for polymer 3. The second plateau spreads from ∼250 to ∼550 °C for polymers 1, 2, and 5, ∼400 to ∼600 °C for polymer 3 and ∼300 to ∼550 °C for polymer 8. On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %), the decomposition is not associated with a simple loss of ligands but rather with a ligand decomposition. This is particularly obvious when the residual mass of the materials at 800 °C or above corresponds to less than 10% of the total mass, which strongly suggests the formation of volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of polymers 1, 2, and 3 leads to the conclusion that the phenyl-containing polymer is more stable by ∼10 °C than that for the p-tolyl but is less stable by ∼50 °C than that for the p-methoxyphenyl (Figure S11, ). On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %) for the TGA traces of polymers 9 and 11, the thermal decomposition is associated with a simple loss of ligands. For 9, the presence of more than one plateau, even small, suggests ligand decomposition without the formation of organometallic volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of 9 and 11 indicates that the phenyl-containing polymer is less stable by about 35 °C than the methoxyphenyl-containing polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability of the Coordination Polymers

The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 8 exhibit two plateaus (Figure S10, ). The first one spreads from room temperature to ~200 °C for polymers 1, 2, 5 and 8 and from room temperature to about 225 °C for polymer 3. The second plateau spreads from ~250 to ~550 °C for polymers 1, 2, and 5, ~400 to ~600 °C for polymer 3 and ~300 to ~550 °C for polymer 8. On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %), the decomposition is not associated with a simple loss of ligands but rather with a ligand decomposition. This is particularly obvious when the residual mass of the materials at 800 °C or above corresponds to less than 10% of the total mass, which strongly suggests the formation of volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of polymers 1, 2, and 3 leads to the conclusion that the phenyl-containing polymer is more stable by ~10 °C than that for the p-tolyl but is less stable by ~50 °C than that for the p-methoxyphenyl (Figure S11, ). On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %) for the TGA traces of polymers 9 and 11, the thermal decomposition is associated with a simple loss of ligands. For 9, the presence of more than one plateau, even small, suggests ligand decomposition without the formation of organometallic volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of 9 and 11 indicates that the phenyl-containing polymer is less stable by about 35 °C than the methoxyphenyl-containing polymer.

elements.content: The solid-state absorption (black), excitation (red), and emission (blue) spectra and photophysical data of polymers 1–5, 8, 9, and 11 are shown in Figures – and in Tables and . Their white coloration infers that the absorption bands are expected to be placed below 400 nm. Indeed, absorption bands centered at ∼320 nm and a long tail in the low energy side are noted. Often, features exceeding 400 nm for the polymers are observed in the solid state absorption spectra, notably for 3, 5, and 8. These features are assigned to the spin forbidden S0 → T n (n = 1, 2, 3, etc.) absorptions normally weak for solution spectra but often observable in the solid-state spectra. This assignment is based upon the proximity of these bands to the observed emissions, which exhibit microsecond time scale decays (Table ) attributable to phosphorescence. The large relative intensity, despite their spin forbidden character, is because the Beer–Lambert law does not apply in the solid. This common phenomenon has been observed before. Generally, the Cu4I4-containing species exhibit two emission bands called high and low energy bands. A relevant literature overview of the assignments of the two excited states is provided here. The nature of these two emissions was previously studied by different research teams. Indeed, Ford and his collaborators addressed this problem first using ab initio methods and more recently using density functional theory (DFT) computations. The outcome of these investigations is that these two excited states are either cluster centered (CC*, that is, within the Cu4X4 skeleton) or halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT). Vega and Saillard reported similar conclusions. Using DFT calculations, Perruchas, Poilot, and co-workers recently reported on the nature of these low and high energy emission bands with a slight modification to the main conclusion. The low energy emission (T1 → S0) is due to a combination of a halide-to-copper charge transfer transition (XMCT) and of a copper-centered transition (3d → 4s, 4p, that is, CC*), which is essentially independent of the nature of the ligand (but not the Cu···Cu distance). The high-energy emission (T2 → S0) is assigned to 3XLCT/3MLCT mixed transition. Because of the strong structural similarity of the Cu4I4 core in polymers 1–8, these same assignments can, at first glance, be suspected in this work.

Polymer 8 represents an interesting case where the emission maximum of the high energy band is placed outside this spectral window at 595 and 640 nm at 298 and 77 K, respectively, which is the most red-shifted luminescence in this series. One expects that the CC* emissions are sensitive to the Cu···Cu separation in the Cu4I4 core. This expected trend is indeed qualitatively observed. Polymers 3 and 8 exhibit the shortest Cu···Cu separations (2.721 and 2.722 Å, respectively, based on the data summarized in Figure ) and the longest wavelength of the emission maxima (550 and 640 nm, respectively, at 77 K). Similarly, polymers 2, 4, and 5 exhibit the longest Cu···Cu separations (2.738, 2.741, and 2.730 (A)/2.735 (B)Å, respectively) and the shortest wavelength of the emission maxima (510, 495, and 495 nm, respectively). Finally, polymer 1 exhibits an intermediate situation (d(Cu···Cu) = 2.726 Å; λmax = 520 nm). Ideally, the position of the pure electronic transitions (i.e., 0–0 peaks) is more appropriate for this correlation, but these unstructured broad bands do not provide this information. Moreover, the nature of the substitution (H vs Me vs Br) and the position of the substitution on the aryl group should slightly influence the position of this emission band rendering the search for a perfect linear relationship more difficult. Nonetheless, this qualitative comparison allows for a confirmation of the nature of the emissive excited state containing the CC* contribution.

elements.content: The electronic spectra of the rhomboid-containing polymers 9 and 11 are gathered in Figure (and those of compounds 10, 12, and 13 are placed in Figures S12 and S13, ). The emission bands exhibit a maximum in the vicinity of 400 nm and either a long tail or a shoulder on the low-energy side of the band. These emission band shapes are clearly reminiscent of that previously reported by us on similar rhomboid motifs (S2Cu(μ-X)CuS2; X = Br, I). Based on the emission lifetimes in the microsecond time scale (Table ), these emissions are also phosphorescence. A M/XLCT assignment for these emissions is proposed on a previous series of computations using extended Hückel MO calculations on related bimetallic species Ag2(μ-X)2(dmb)2 (X = Cl, Br, I; dmb = 1,8-diisocyanomenthane).

elements.content: This study has shown that in contrast to the reaction of CuI with the ligands ArS(CH2)3SAr, ArS(CH2)5SAr, and ArSCH2CCCH2SAr, the coordination of bis(arylthiomethanes) is quite insensitive with respect to the substitution pattern of the aryl cycle and the metal-to-ligand ratio employed. Unlike other studies, the outcome of the self-assembly reaction is also not affected by the CuI-to-ligand ratio used. The polymers develop over the crystallographic glide planes zigzagging with a small deviation of the Cu4I4 centroid of 0.07 Å for 1A up to a large deviation of 0.46 Å observed in the 5B chain of compound 5. In all cases, 1D necklace-like coordination polymers incorporating Cu4I4 clusters of the closed-cubane type are formed. Crystal structure determinations at variable temperature reveal that when the temperature is increased in [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n a change from the monoclinic space group C2/c to P21/c occurs, whereas for [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L4)2] n no phase transition is observed in the 160 K range. In contrast, the outcome of the reaction of CuBr with ArSCH2SAr is hardly predicable. In no case could assembly of a Cu4Br4S4 cluster be achieved, and invariably formation of compounds containing dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboids was observed. One particular case within the CuBr series is compound 12 assembled with bis(meta-tolylthio)methane, which exhibits the same topology as the Cu4I4 derivatives (1D chains zigzagging over the c glide planes of C2/c). But there is no evident tendency to rationalize the quite diverging Cu···Cu separations and dimensionalities of CuBr-based dithioether compounds 9–13. Noteworthy, neither CuI nor CuBr forms any 2D or 3D networks with ArSCH2SAr. The unprecedented presence of dangling η1-dithioethers in Cu(I) complexes 10 and 13 opens the possibility to use them as metalloligands to “trap” other soft metal ions to construct heterometallic assemblies, a concept widely used in L n M(η1-dppm) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

This study has shown that in contrast to the reaction of CuI with the ligands ArS(CH2)3SAr, ArS(CH2)5SAr, and ArSCH2CCCH2SAr, the coordination of bis(arylthiomethanes) is quite insensitive with respect to the substitution pattern of the aryl cycle and the metal-to-ligand ratio employed. Unlike other studies, the outcome of the self-assembly reaction is also not affected by the CuI-to-ligand ratio used. The polymers develop over the crystallographic glide planes zigzagging with a small deviation of the Cu4I4 centroid of 0.07 Å for 1A up to a large deviation of 0.46 Å observed in the 5B chain of compound 5. In all cases, 1D necklace-like coordination polymers incorporating Cu4I4 clusters of the closed-cubane type are formed. Crystal structure determinations at variable temperature reveal that when the temperature is increased in [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L1)2] n  a change from the monoclinic space group C2/c to P21/c occurs, whereas for [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}(μ-L4)2] n  no phase transition is observed in the 160 K range. In contrast, the outcome of the reaction of CuBr with ArSCH2SAr is hardly predicable. In no case could assembly of a Cu4Br4S4 cluster be achieved, and invariably formation of compounds containing dinuclear Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu rhomboids was observed. One particular case within the CuBr series is compound 12 assembled with bis(meta-tolylthio)methane, which exhibits the same topology as the Cu4I4 derivatives (1D chains zigzagging over the c glide planes of C2/c). But there is no evident tendency to rationalize the quite diverging Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations and dimensionalities of CuBr-based dithioether compounds 9-13. Noteworthy, neither CuI nor CuBr forms any 2D or 3D networks with ArSCH2SAr. The unprecedented presence of dangling η1-dithioethers in Cu(I) complexes 10 and 13 opens the possibility to use them as metalloligands to "trap" other soft metal ions to construct heterometallic assemblies, a concept widely used in L n M(η1-dppm) complexes.

elements.content: A strong luminescence is detected for all polymers, all exhibiting emission lifetime in the microsecond time scale (i.e., phosphorescence). The polymers containing the Cu4I4 core (1–8) exhibit the low-energy band and sometimes a weaker high-energy band typically observed for such a motif. The nature of the low energy band was addressed by DFT and TDDFT computations and is predicted to be a mixture of cluster-centered (CC*) and metal/halide-to-ligand charger transfer (M/XLCT). A qualitative linear relationship between the Cu···Cu distance and the emission maxima corroborates the CC* contribution to the nature of the excited states. The emission of the rhomboid-containing materials is assigned to M/XLCT based on literature work on similar motifs. In juxtaposition to the present work on the coordination chemistry of CuX salts with the small-bite ligands ArSCH2SAr, we are currently investigating the construction of CuX networks assembled with dithioether ligands incorporating extended flexible spacer chains such as ArS(CH2)7SAr and ArS(CH2)8SAr.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

CuI and CuBr were purchased from Acros; the thiols were purchased from Alfa Aesar and Aldrich. The dithioethers L1-L6 were prepared as described in the literature. The synthesis of polymer 1 has been published elsewhere. Experimental details concerning the preparation of L8 and polymers 2-12 are presented in the .

elements.content: Data collection of compound 2 was conducted on a Stoe IPDS diffractometer: data collection with Expose in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999), cell determination and refinement with Cell in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999), integration with Integrate in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999); numerical absorption correction with Faceit in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999). Data collection of compounds 5, 8, and 10 was conducted on a CrysAlis CCD, Oxford Diffraction Ltd.: CCD (D8 three-circle goniometer), cell determination, refinement, and integration with CrysAlis RED, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., version 1.171.32.37; empirical absorption correction with CrysAlis RED using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved applying direct and Fourier methods using SHELXS-97 (G. M. Sheldrick, SHELXS97, University of Göttingen 1997) and refined with SHELXL-97 (G. M. Sheldrick, SHELXL97, University of Göttingen 1997). Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Database. Tables S1–S4, , contain further information about the data collection and structure refinement of all compounds described herein. A summary of the crystallochemical data for all structures is given in Table S5, .

X-ray Crystallography

Data collection of compound 2 was conducted on a Stoe IPDS diffractometer: data collection with Expose in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999), cell determination and refinement with Cell in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999), integration with Integrate in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999); numerical absorption correction with Faceit in IPDS (STOE & Cie GmbH, 1999). Data collection of compounds 5, 8, and 10 was conducted on a CrysAlis CCD, Oxford Diffraction Ltd.: CCD (D8 three-circle goniometer), cell determination, refinement, and integration with CrysAlis RED, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., version 1.171.32.37; empirical absorption correction with CrysAlis RED using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures were solved applying direct and Fourier methods using SHELXS-97 (G. M. Sheldrick, SHELXS97, University of Göttingen 1997) and refined with SHELXL-97 (G. M. Sheldrick, SHELXL97, University of Göttingen 1997). Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Database. Tables S1-S4, , contain further information about the data collection and structure refinement of all compounds described herein. A summary of the crystallochemical data for all structures is given in Table S5, .

elements.content: The X-ray intensity data of 3, 9, and 11 were measured on a Bruker Kappa APEX II DUO CCD system equipped with a TRIUMPH curved-crystal monochromator and a Mo fine-focus tube (λ = 0.71073 Å). The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package using a narrow-frame algorithm. Data were corrected for absorption effects using the multiscan method (SADABS). The colorless single crystals of 1, 4, 12, and 13 were mounted (silicon grease as glue) on a Nonius Kappa Apex-II CCD diffractometer equipped with a nitrogen jet stream low-temperature system (Oxford Cryosystems). Diffraction data (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) were recorded for 1 and 4 at five temperatures (115, 155, 195, 235, and 275 K). A very poor and untreatable diffraction pattern was found at 275 K for 1. Data for 12 (1D ribbon) and for 13 (discrete molecule) were recorded at 115 K only. The OLEX2 package was used for analysis of these last structures. Lattice parameters were obtained by least-squares fit to the optimized setting angles of the entire set of collected reflections. No significant intensity decay or temperature drift was observed during data collection, except at 275 K for 1. Data were reduced by using the DENZO (1) and SAINT (4, 12, 13) software with numerical absorption multiscan corrections of Blessing for 1 and SADABS for 4, 12, and 13. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS97 (13) and SUPERFLIP (1, 4, and 12) programs. Refinements were carried out by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL97 program. A disorder of one Ar ring in 12 concerning the meta-position of the CH3 group (3-methyl vs 5-methyl) was observed and refined to quasi-equivalent occupation site ratio of 0.56 vs 0.44; a similar probability to find the Me substituent on both rotation meta sites. Two rather strong residual peaks on difference Fourier (on the order of 3 e/Å3) were found in the 115 K structure of 4 at 1.1 Å from S atoms. Attempts to refine this problem as disorder in S positions failed (increase of all statistics). On the other hand, the heights of these peaks decrease with increasing temperature to some 1.8 e/Å3 at 275 K. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and included in final refinement in a riding model with the isotropic temperature parameters set to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq for methylene CH2 and aryl CH carbon atoms and to 1.5U eq for methyl CH3 groups.

cln_elements.content: The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 8 exhibit two plateaus (Figure S10, ). The first one spreads from room temperature to ∼200 °C for polymers 1, 2, 5 and 8 and from room temperature to about 225 °C for polymer 3. The second plateau spreads from ∼250 to ∼550 °C for polymers 1, 2, and 5, ∼400 to ∼600 °C for polymer 3 and ∼300 to ∼550 °C for polymer 8. On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %), the decomposition is not associated with a simple loss of ligands but rather with a ligand decomposition. This is particularly obvious when the residual mass of the materials at 800 °C or above corresponds to less than 10% of the total mass, which strongly suggests the formation of volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of polymers 1, 2, and 3 leads to the conclusion that the phenyl-containing polymer is more stable by ∼10 °C than that for the p-tolyl but is less stable by ∼50 °C than that for the p-methoxyphenyl (Figure S11, ). On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %) for the TGA traces of polymers 9 and 11, the thermal decomposition is associated with a simple loss of ligands. For 9, the presence of more than one plateau, even small, suggests ligand decomposition without the formation of organometallic volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of 9 and 11 indicates that the phenyl-containing polymer is less stable by about 35 °C than the methoxyphenyl-containing polymer.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability of the Coordination Polymers

The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) traces of polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 8 exhibit two plateaus (Figure S10, ). The first one spreads from room temperature to ~200 °C for polymers 1, 2, 5 and 8 and from room temperature to about 225 °C for polymer 3. The second plateau spreads from ~250 to ~550 °C for polymers 1, 2, and 5, ~400 to ~600 °C for polymer 3 and ~300 to ~550 °C for polymer 8. On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %), the decomposition is not associated with a simple loss of ligands but rather with a ligand decomposition. This is particularly obvious when the residual mass of the materials at 800 °C or above corresponds to less than 10% of the total mass, which strongly suggests the formation of volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of polymers 1, 2, and 3 leads to the conclusion that the phenyl-containing polymer is more stable by ~10 °C than that for the p-tolyl but is less stable by ~50 °C than that for the p-methoxyphenyl (Figure S11, ). On the basis of the difference in relative mass losses (in %) for the TGA traces of polymers 9 and 11, the thermal decomposition is associated with a simple loss of ligands. For 9, the presence of more than one plateau, even small, suggests ligand decomposition without the formation of organometallic volatiles. The comparison of derivative traces of 9 and 11 indicates that the phenyl-containing polymer is less stable by about 35 °C than the methoxyphenyl-containing polymer.

decomposition temperature.condition: presence of more than one plateau
